body_html:
tf.Variable s are not tensors, and neither are SparseTensors
…
On Fri, Dec 1, 2017 at 4:21 PM, Yan Facai (颜发才) ***@***.***> wrote: At first I think a variable is not a tensor until I see the official document: Tensors - Programmers' Guide <https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/tensors> Some types of tensors are special, and these will be covered in other units of the Programmer's guide. The main ones are: tf.Variable tf.Constant tf.Placeholder tf.SparseTensor If I understand it correctly, there are only one kind of Tensor in C++ side: it can be mutable or immutable which depends on dtype. However, it is not that simple in Python side: - tf.Constant return immutable tf.Tensor. - tf.Variable doesn't return tf.Tensor, however they are treated as same class in most cases, say tf.add. I think tf.Variable is a wrapper for mutable tf.Tensor, right? It seems that doc of tf.Print is accurate as tf.identity, what confuse us is how to regard tf.Variable: is it a tensor or not? tf.Print: Returns: Same tensor as input_. tf.identity: Returns: A Tensor. Has the same type as input. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#14788 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAATxUhn3SLxpKB9OQzUil42J-O4TTwrks5s8JgmgaJpZM4QnEuP> .
-- - Alex
body_text:
tf.Variable s are not tensors, and neither are SparseTensors
…
On Fri, Dec 1, 2017 at 4:21 PM, Yan Facai (颜发才) ***@***.***> wrote:
 At first I think a variable is not a tensor until I see the official
 document:

 Tensors - Programmers' Guide
 <https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/tensors>

 Some types of tensors are special, and these will be covered in other
 units of the Programmer's guide. The main ones are:

  tf.Variable
 tf.Constant
  tf.Placeholder
  tf.SparseTensor

 If I understand it correctly, there are only one kind of Tensor in C++
 side: it can be mutable or immutable which depends on dtype. However, it
 is not that simple in Python side:

    - tf.Constant return immutable tf.Tensor.
    - tf.Variable doesn't return tf.Tensor, however they are treated as
    same class in most cases, say tf.add. I think tf.Variable is a wrapper
    for mutable tf.Tensor, right?

 It seems that doc of tf.Print is accurate as tf.identity, what confuse us
 is how to regard tf.Variable: is it a tensor or not?

 tf.Print:

 Returns:
 Same tensor as input_.

 tf.identity:

 Returns:
 A Tensor. Has the same type as input.

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#14788 (comment)>,
 or mute the thread
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAATxUhn3SLxpKB9OQzUil42J-O4TTwrks5s8JgmgaJpZM4QnEuP>
 .


-- 
 - Alex
body:
tf.Variable s are not tensors, and neither are SparseTensors

On Fri, Dec 1, 2017 at 4:21 PM, Yan Facai (颜发才) <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> At first I think a variable is not a tensor until I see the official
> document:
>
> Tensors - Programmers' Guide
> <https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/tensors>
>
> Some types of tensors are special, and these will be covered in other
> units of the Programmer's guide. The main ones are:
>
>  tf.Variable
> tf.Constant
>  tf.Placeholder
>  tf.SparseTensor
>
> If I understand it correctly, there are only one kind of Tensor in C++
> side: it can be mutable or immutable which depends on dtype. However, it
> is not that simple in Python side:
>
>    - tf.Constant return immutable tf.Tensor.
>    - tf.Variable doesn't return tf.Tensor, however they are treated as
>    same class in most cases, say tf.add. I think tf.Variable is a wrapper
>    for mutable tf.Tensor, right?
>
> It seems that doc of tf.Print is accurate as tf.identity, what confuse us
> is how to regard tf.Variable: is it a tensor or not?
>
> tf.Print:
>
> Returns:
> Same tensor as input_.
>
> tf.identity:
>
> Returns:
> A Tensor. Has the same type as input.
>
> —
